fields.label_text:
LONG-CASE CLOCK
ENGLISH; about 1690
Marquetry of walnut and various woods.

Inscribed:  JAMES BEWERLY-LONDON

MONTH-GOING LONG CASE CLOCK
Marquetry of Walnut and other woods on an oak carcase
Inscribed 'James Beverly London', about 1700
Bequeathed by V. B. Crowther-Beynon
Museum number: W.19-1952

James Beverly was apprenticed to Robert Doore in 1684. He became a member of the Clockmakers' Company in 1691.

The marquetry on the case is particularly fine, displaying a mixture of arabesques, birds and dragons. The extremely fine matting in the centre of the clock face was probably made using a roller. The fact that the maker's name is inscribed on the dial between the numbers VII and V indicates that the clock dates from about 1700. Before that date the maker's name is more commonly found beneath the dial and is therefore visible only when the door  to the face is opened. It was also common on long case clocks made before 1700 for the maker's name and place of work to be followed by the Latin word "fecit", meaning "made (by)". This too became outmoded as long case clockmaking progressed.

The weight driven, two train movement has an externally mounted count wheel which controls the hour striking on a single bell. It has a locking-plate striking train. The anchor escapement has been partially replaced and the mechanism is made from steel and brass.

[Clock store label]

fields.descriptive_line:
Arabesque marquetry of walnut and other woods on an oak carcase with brass mounts.

Movement: Month going, brass and steel, weight driven, two train movement. The dial silvered with Roman numerals engraved in black.
fields.physical_description:
Case:
Hood of architecture form with corner columns on a straight-sided case, on a stepped base. The hood, which is connected to the body of the case with an ogee moulding, decorated with arabesque marquetry, has a ¾ column at either side of the front and similar ¼ columns at the back, each with brass bases and capitals, and veneered with arabesque marquetry. The frame of the glass is similarly decorated and has a small brass keyhole escutcheon. Above this is a frieze filled with an arabesque fretted design, above which is a moulded cornice.

The straight-sided case is connected to its base by a concave moulding. The front surfaces of both decorated with marquetry of arabesques, birdlike creatures and Berainesque motifs. The sides have plain veneer (of walnut?) with panels outlined in stringing. A cross-banded bead edges the door panel, which has a round glass window framed in a band of brass, and a small brass keyhole escutcheon. 

Dial:
The 12 inch square dial has a brass dial plate with matted centre and square calendar aperture bordered by an engraved drapery pattern, behind which is a silvered calendar ring. Consists of a pierced steel hour and minute hand and a small seconds hand. The face has a second hand with a dial similar to the larger one, two winding holes and a date aperture. The corner spandrels of brass with arabesque decoration show each pair of amorini holding a crown.

More details regarding the dial, movement and hands can be found in an unsigned and undated report in the Furniture Department local records.
fields.dimensions: Height: 221.5 cm, Width: 57 cm, Depth: 31.3 cm
fields.materials_techniques:
Long case clock. Arabesque marquetry of walnut and other woods on an oak carcase with brass mounts.

Movement: Month going, brass and steel, weight driven, two train movement. The dial silvered with Roman numerals engraved in black.
fields.label:
LONG-CASE CLOCK
ENGLISH; about 1690
Marquetry of walnut and various woods.

Inscribed:  JAMES BEWERLY-LONDON [pre October 2000]
MONTH-GOING LONG CASE CLOCK
Marquetry of Walnut and other woods on an oak carcase
Inscribed 'James Beverly London', about 1700
Bequeathed by V. B. Crowther-Beynon
Museum number: W.19-1952

James Beverly was apprenticed to Robert Doore in 1684. He became a member of the Clockmakers' Company in 1691.

The marquetry on the case is particularly fine, displaying a mixture of arabesques, birds and dragons. The extremely fine matting in the centre of the clock face was probably made using a roller. The fact that the maker's name is inscribed on the dial between the numbers VII and V indicates that the clock dates from about 1700. Before that date the maker's name is more commonly found beneath the dial and is therefore visible only when the door  to the face is opened. It was also common on long case clocks made before 1700 for the maker's name and place of work to be followed by the Latin word "fecit", meaning "made (by)". This too became outmoded as long case clockmaking progressed.

The weight driven, two train movement has an externally mounted count wheel which controls the hour striking on a single bell. It has a locking-plate striking train. The anchor escapement has been partially replaced and the mechanism is made from steel and brass.

[Clock store label] [01/01/2001]
fields.history_note:
James Beverly longcase clock, the bequest of V B Crowther-Beynon of Westfield, Beckingham Kent

Notes from R.P. 52/1176

7 October 1926 minute paper, H Clifford Smith
Smith met Crowther-Beynon at the Society of Antiquaries and learned that, as he was the last of his family, he intended to bequeath his inherited furniture to the Museum.  Among items selected by Smith as "of special interest and importance" is "A walnut tall case clock decorated with seaweed marquetry.  By James Beverly, London.  About 1700".

12/5/52 Bequest Form
lists among 11 articles bequeathed:
"1 long case clock of walnut & other woods marquetry.  By James Beverley, London.  About 1700      W19-1952".  The description "decorated with seaweed" is crossed out.

20/10/26 R.P. 8019 Minute Papers
lists items selected by HCS for bequest to the Museum by Crowther Beynon.  It is from "Furniture which he had inherited".  Smith selected pieces he considered "of special interest and importance" including the tall case clock by Beverley about 1700.

The Director (Brackett) calls the bequest "a valuable addition to our collections".

Object sampling carried out by Jo Darrah, V&A Science; drawer/slide reference 1/112.
fields.historical_context_note:
Arabesque Marquetry:
Two woods were typically used in arabesque marquetry, box or holly for the pattern and walnut for the ground (R. Edwards, Dictionary of English Furniture, p 266). Arabesque marquetry differs from floral marquetry in that all of the elements of design are cut in a single operation as opposed to piece by piece. This technique was used by Gerrit Jensen (1667-1715) amongst others (A. Bowett, English Furniture 1660-1714, 199-201).

Comparable Clocks:
A floral marquetry long-case clock was sold by Allan Smith Antique Clocks between 2005 and 2013. The following information about Beverly was extracted from www.allansmithantiqueclocks.co.uk (accessed on 07/02/2014): James Beverly (sometimes spelt Beverley) was apprenticed in June 1684 to Robert Dore (Doore) until 1691.
